outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: Data Science is about problem solving

all_paragraphs: Data Science is a fantastic career to pursue, but nothing comes free. You need to pay the price and put in the work for months or years to see the first fruits. It’s not an easy road but a very satisfying one. So I’ll focus on skills you should start honing and what you need in order to succeed.

I need to say that first: data science requires you to learn statistics and linear algebra. And it’s better if you do that before you start going into machine learning algorithms and do more advanced material. Without statistics you’d be often at a loss why certain methods don’t work, you won’t be able to interpret results properly and correct them in a good direction.
You’ll be working twice as hard and long for something which is not necessary.

The other technical skill you need is coding in Python. You need to feel at ease with Python as you’ll often need to prototype your solutions to a given problem. If you can do that quickly, you can then start iterating and arriving at a better solution. If that part slows you down and you need to think each time how to put your solution into working code, then you end up forgetting about the problem you’re trying to solve by losing yourself in unimportant technical details.

Don’t go this way — it’s better to spend a couple of months polishing your statistics and Python skills than later having to return to the same material over and over when you’ll need to solve a data science problem.

The best way to practice problem solving is… by problem solving. This is a practical skill. You can start coding and implementing algorithms to small problems, go on Kaggle and find a dataset/problem for yourself. It’s all about finding new problems and trying to solve them.
Problem solving is a mindset which becomes a skill with enough practice.
From a non-technical standpoint, there are two main skills you need to develop as a data scientist.
First of all, you’ll need to visualize your results. That can be

or many other things. The important thing is whatever form you choose it needs to be clear what you’re presenting — both to you and to others. Visualizing your results helps greatly in understanding data and a problem you’re trying to solve at a time. Especially if you’re confronting a new, large dataset and you have no idea what to expect.

Then visualization can help immensely in showing others why your results matter and how to use them, whether you present them to other developers, data scientists or business people. Visual data is easy to grasp, because you don’t have to imagine numbers — you see them straight away.

Secondly, communicating in a clear, honest way is very important. If you can deliver a short talk about your results, presenting them on a graph at the same time, you’ll do a great job which will allow others to interact with you, learn and respond. Of course, you don’t need to have any public speaking skills, I’m talking about small teams of a couple of people you’ll be presenting the results to, but it’s really important that you can make a coherent story out of your data. This will be helpful both in large corporations, small startups and if you’re a freelance data scientist. People understand through seeing more than through reading or hearing.
